person.note: See Introduction 6.1.6.2.1.
The inscription is dated.
The inscription is dated.
The inscription mentions Ex 34:7, but see Introduction 6.9.
Date according to Strubbe, “Curses,” 77.
Based on father’s name, Fikhman, “CPJ IV,” 294, n. 18, is sure he is Jewish, but see Introduction 6.6.1.
The ostracon is dated.
See Introduction 6.1.6.2.1.
The inscription is dated.
See Introduction 2.1, and 2.7.2.

The inscription in which he is mentioned refers to Σαββατισταῖς θεοῦ (sabbathians of god) and συναγωγέα (synagogue). However, on this term see Introduction 6.4.1.2.3. IJO 2 rejected this inscription’s Jewishness and did not include it in his corpus, see p. 495, n. 14.

The inscription was considered Jewish because of the combination ̓Ωνείας ἀρχιερεύς (Onias, High-Priest) found in it, perhaps referring to a number of Jewish high-priests from the 2nd century BCE, but is rejected by CIJ on the grounds that neither is uniquely Jewish, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.3, but see also under Honi (S-H/M), n. 1. The inscription includes the pagan formula Θ(εοῖς) Κ(αταχθονίοις) (to the gods of the underworld), see Introduction 6.10.2.1.
Jewishness may be suggested based on son’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The editor dated the papyrus to the Roman period.
The inscription is a pagan dedicatory inscription to the God Pan. Jewishness may be suggested based on son’s name, but see under Abraham (B/M), n. 1, and Introduction 6.6.5, and 6.10.2.
The inscription is dated.
Jewishness suggested based on vicinity to CJZC46, but see Introduction 6.5.9. That tomb also has no unique Jewish features, see Introduction 6.5.5.
See Introduction 6.1.6.2.1.
The inscription is dated.
See Introduction 2.1. On the interchange of ι and ει see introduction 2.3.3.2.
In this second case the name is reconstructed. It is the editor’s guess that it refers to the same person.
His son paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.1.
The ostraca are dated, but the dating of CPJ 287 is doubtful.
See Introduction 2.1, and above, n. 2.
Jewishness suggested based on the fact that the ostracon was found in the “Jewish quarter” of Edfu, but see Introduction 6.1.5.2.

state.note: Gaius (25) Julius (27), Gaius (26) Julius (28) Candidus (2)’s son

person.note: See Introduction 2.1.
Found in the same tomb with Judah (83), see Introduction 6.5.5.
In Greek – θ’.
Jewishness suggested because of some names found in the cave, but there is nothing necessarily Jewish about them, see Introduction 6.5.5.
For the single consonant see Introduction 2.3.3.4.
Found in a tomb with Joshua (21) and Judah (77), see Introduction 6.5.5.
Inscription c is dated.
In Greek – κα’.
Jewishness indicated by father’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
So in e.
So in c.
In Greek – ο’.
This tomb is occupied by a family whose names are repeated over the generations. A genealogical reconstruction may suggest that the patriarch of the tomb was Judah (78), see Introduction 6.5.5.
Considered by the editor Jewish because of vicinity to Jewish tombs, but see Introduction 6.5.5.
The inscription is dated.
Applebaum mentioned this person as possibly Jewish, because of Greek names he considered Jewish found in its vicinity, but see Introduction 6.5.5.
In Greek – ἐπὶ ἀρχόντων.
This is a Jewish politeuma inscription, see Introduction 6.4.2.2.
The date is reconstructed by the editors.

Jewishness suggested based on a proximity to a Shabtai (26) on this ostracon, but see Introduction 6.6.6, and on the possibility that the name refers to the city of this name in Palestine, but even if true, see Introduction 6.8.
The ostracon is dated.
Jewishness may be suggested based on title archisynagogus mentioned in the inscription, but in Greece this is not decisive, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.5.1.
So according to some mss this is his name, but the lectio difficilior is Atomus, and I suspect some well-wishing scribe corrected it.
In Greek – μάγον εἴναι.
Described in the text as ̓Ιουδαῖον Κύπριον δὲ τὸ γένος (a Cyprian Jew by birth), see Introduction 6.1.1.1.

Round about this year he is mentioned in Josephus as persuading Drusilla (1) (L/F) in vol. 1, p. 343, to marry Felix, the Procurator of Judaea. It could not have been earlier, because in 53 he married another woman, and it could not have been much later because he no longer held the position after 56 CE.
See Introduction 6.1.6.2.1.
The inscription is dated.
See Introduction 6.1.6.2.1.
The inscription is dated.
In the Latin translation of the Vulgate to the apocryphal 3 Ezra 5:32 we find the name Barchus, perhaps for the Hebrew ברקוס.
This is a list of Roman soldiers.
Jewishness suggested based on the Semitic names of the soldiers in this list, but they need not be Jews, see Introduction 6.6.1.
The papyrus is dated.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. In the Latin translation of the Vulgate to the apocryphal 3 Ezra 5:32 we find the name Barchus, perhaps for the Hebrew ברקוס.

person.note: In Latin – L.L.

The inscription, containing the names of three freedmen, was considered Jewish because of the names – Baricha, Zabda and Achiba – but all three, although Semitic, need not be understood as Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.1.

This person is probably Idumean, see n. 1 above, but see also Justi, INB, 64, where Βαργουσνᾶς is recorded, as a Persian (female) name, and WGE, 197, where Βάργος is recorded. For the interchange of κ and γ see Introduction 2.3.3.6.
See Introduction 6.1.6.2.1.
The inscription is dated.
This person is probably Idumean, see n. 1 above, but see also Josephus (e.g AJ 5:201) where Βαράκος is the form recorded for the biblical name ברק.

note.ref: See above, n. 11. The inscription is dated.
See above, n. 12. This person is probably Idumean, see n. 1 above, but see also Josephus (e.g AJ 5:201) where Βαράκος is the form recorded for the biblical name ברק.

person.note: Jewishness suggested based on 1. the possible Semitic בר (son) element in the father’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.2.1; and 2. his son’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.4.1.
So in CIJ. JIWE 1, 191, read this to mean “the foreigner.”
Jewishness is indicated by 1. a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1; and 2. the Hebrew שלום, see Introduction 6.2.3.
The Hebrew may indicate that the inscription is late, see Introduction 6.2.3.
See previous note.
See Introduction 2.7.2.
Jewishness may be suggested based on relative’s name (Shabtit [9]), but see Introduction 6.6.6.
The papyrus is dated.
In Demotic script, see Introduction 2.9.
Jewishness suggested based on vicinity to persons with biblical names mentioned in the same document, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
The editor dated the inscription to the Ptolemaic period.
See Introduction 2.1.
Found in the cemetery of Gamarat, Carthage, see Introduction 6.5.4.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
His manumission with two others is described as ἄφετοι.
In Russia, on the north-eastern coast of the Black Sea.
This slave was manumitted in τῆς συναγωγη τῶν ̓Ιουδαίων (the synagogue of the Jews), but he need not be Jewish, see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.3, and Gibson, Jewish Manumission Inscriptions, 150-2.
These are the dates of King Cotys mentioned in the inscription.

His daughter is described in this inscription as ̓Ιουδέα (Jewess), see Introduction 6.1.4. However, he is not, and in this case may not have been one, see Introduction 6.1.4.1, and Kraemer, HTR 82 (1989) 44.
Applebaum thought this a Jewish (biblical?) name, but not CJZC, and see Introduction 6.6.3.
In Greek – ̓Αλεξανδρέος.
Found in a Jewish cemetery in Palestine, see Introduction 6.5.7.
This name appears after the description of the deceased as Alexandrian. The editor translated the text of (the family of the) Kochadoi.
Dating according to CIJ II, p. 119.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3. The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
See Introduction 6.1.6.2.1.
The inscription is dated.
He is described as participating in this Jewish Christian dispute, without actually being designated “Jew,” yet he champions the Jewish cause.
These are Pope Silvester’s dates.
The editors maintain that one can also read the name as Εβωνο, but both forms are unknown.
Jewishness indicated by father’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1.
In Greek – μελλάχων.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3. The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
The deceased is described as “ebreus” (Hebrew), see Introduction 6.1.2.

His conversion proclamation is described with the words: “Contestor, inquit, vos omnes me Judaeorum esse non posse in possessione” (I call you all to witness that I cannot be a Jew), see Introduction 6.1.6.3.
Severus, the bishop of Minorca, wrote in a letter dated to this year about the conversion of the Jews of Minorca.
Described in the text as of the “natione Judaeus.”
The inscription was found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3. It is accompanied by the Hebrew שלום על משכבהו (peace on his place of rest), see Introduction 6.2.2.
See Introduction 2.7.2.

CPJ1, p. 201, suggested that the name is derived from the Hebrew – יפיע, but that is not a recognized biblical name, see Introduction 6.6.2, and previous note. Jewishness may be suggested based on father’s name, but there is no indication that this name was specifically Jewish, see under Dositheus (G/M), n. 1.
See previous note.
The ostracon is dated.
Considered by the editor Jewish because of vicinity to Jewish tombs, but see Introduction 6.5.5.
The inscription is dated.
On the Aphrodisias inscription see Introduction 6.1.6.1.1.
Both forms are recorded in the treatise, see Introduction 2.7.2.
See in vol. 1 under Philip (5) (G/M) p. 310.

He is described in the text as ἠ̃σαν δὲ καὶ ̓Ιουδαῖοι … ἀποκριθεὶς δέ τις ἐξ α̓τῶν ἂρχων̓νόματι ̓́Ιρεος (and there were also Jews … the most respectable one among their archons, was called Ireos), see Introduction 6.1.1.1.
Described in the text as “Iude[i]s” (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.4.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
Considered by the editor Jewish because of vicinity to Jewish tombs, but see Introduction 6.5.5.
See Introduction 6.1.6.2.1.
The inscription is dated.

Jewishness was suggested based on name (but see Introduction 6.6.2) and on the unique function of “elder” (πρεσβευτῶν) of this person in Italy, perhaps indicating his relation to the Jewish community in Ptoleamais. He may also be mentioned in an epheboi inscription from Cyrene, see J. Reynolds and O. Masson, “Une inscription ephebique de Ptolemaïs (Cyrenaïque),” ZPE 20 (1976) 89, l. 22. However, none of this is decisive.
The man is described as ̓Ιουδ[α]ί[ω]ι (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.2.
The papyrus is dated to these years.
See Introduction 6.1.6.2.1.
The inscription is dated.
The editor assumed his other name, and the name of his father were Jewish, but see under Eirenaius (G/M), n. 1.
The papyrus is dated.

Jewishness suggested by S. Honigman, “Les orientaux en Egypte a l‘epoque Hellenistique et Romaine. Lexique onomastique et commaintaire,” (MA Thesis, Ecole Biblique et Archeologique Française, Jerusalem 1991) 76, based on name, but see Introduction 6.6.2.
The editor dated the ostracon to the Ptolemaic period.
See Introduction 2.1. The assumption that this is the same name is mine. On the interchange of λ and ν see also under Baanathanus (S-G/M) n. 1.
Applebaum mentioned this person as possibly Jewish, but even the editor doubted it, see Introduction 6.5.5.

state.note: Marcus (36) Aurelius (84) Malka (11)’s father, soldier of Emesa

person.note: In Latin – signifer c(ohortis) Hemes(enorum) (=standard bearer of the Emesa regiment).
Jewishness suggested based on son’s Semitic name, but it need not be Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.2.
For the Bar prefix see Introduction 2.2.1.1.5. The form ברנבו is recorded in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 79.

Jewishness indicated by son’s name, see Introduction 6.6.9.1. This person is recorded under Nabas (1) (S-G/M) in vol. 1, p. 439, but not included in the statistics, because it was considered a nickname. For this as a nickname see Williams, JSJ 38 (2007) 324.
See vol. 1, Introduction 7.3, p. 51.
Jewishness suggested based on name and on the element “bar” in it, but there is no evidence that the name is specifically Jewish, see Introduction 6.6.2, and 6.6.2.1, and above, n. 2.
The ostracon is dated.
The editor assumed the name is Jewish, but there is no other indication for this or for other persons mentioned in this papyrus.
The papyrus is dated.
In Russia, on the north-eastern coast of the Black Sea.

This manumission inscription is similar to others performed in the Jewish synagogue in the region, but see Introduction 6.4.1.2.2.3. The opening formula, [Θεῷ̔ψ]ίσ[τῳ παντοκράτ ]ορι (God most high, ruler of all), was also considered as Jewish, but see Introduction 6.10.1.1.
These are the dates of the king mentioned in the inscription, according to IJO 1, BS21.
In Latin “portitor.”
Described in the text as “Iudaeus” (Jew), see Introduction 6.1.1.1.
The letter is dated.
See Introduction 6.1.6.2.1.
The inscription is dated.
CPJ only included this ostracon because it was found together with the Jewish ones, but states “he was probably an Egyptian,” see Introduction 6.1.5.2
The ostracon is dated.
In this papyrus he writes a declaration instead of a Jew, because the latter is illiterate. As he needs to be trusted, he may be Jewish himself, but need not be, see Introduction 6.1.4.1.
The papyrus is dated.
In Latin – qui bixsit plus minus annos LV.
The two inscriptions come from the same location and have the same form. They probably belonged to members of the same family.
Jewishness is decided by 1. a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1; and 2. the Hebrew שלום (peace), see Introduction 6.2.2.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3. The inscription is accompanied by a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1.
In Latin – Senex.

Jewishness indicated by the formula “et si quis ipsum vexaverit ultor erit Deus Israel in saeculum” (and if anyone disturbs him, the God of Israel will be the avenger forever), see Introduction 6.1.3.
Described in the text as “ex Judaeo conversum” (converted from Judaism), see Introduction 6.1.6.3.
Jewishness indicated by son’s name, see Introduction Introduction 6.6.9.1.
On such nicknames see vol. 1, Introduction 6.1.1, p. 46.
His daughter’s freedman paid the Jewish tax, see Introduction 6.1.5.1.
The ostracon is dated.
See Introduction 2.1.
Jewishness indicated by 1. a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1; and 2. the Hebrew word – בשלום (in peace), see Introduction 6.2.2.
In the Crimea.

He is described in the inscription as an Imperial governor of the region of Theodosia (̔ ἐπὶ τῆς Θεοδοσίας), known to the emperor Diocletian. This inscription is a dedication of a synagogue (προσευχήν), but for this term see Introduction 6.4.1.2.1.1.
The inscription is dated.
In Russia, on the north-eastern coast of the Black Sea.
This family manumitted its slave in τῆς συναγωγη τῶν ̓Ιουδαίων (the synagogue of the Jews), see Introdction 6.4.1.2.2.3, and Gibson, Jewish Manumission Inscriptions, 150-2.
These are the dates of King Cotys mentioned in the inscription.
Jewishness suggested based on father’s name, but see Introduction 6.6.4.
The ostracon is dated.
Jewishness suggested based on vicinity to persons with biblical names mentioned in the same document, but see Introduction 6.6.9.2.
In Latin – Alexandriae.

Described in the text as “Erat … Alexandriae Judaeus quidem opulentus monine Urbib” (There was … in Alexandria a certain Jew named Urbib). The entire episode is related in order to tell of his conversion, see Introduction 6.1.6.3.
The editor suggested the times of the Roman Emperor Zenon. These are his regnal years.
The initial publisher thought the inscription Jewish, but there is no grounds for such a claim.
The inscription is not dated. Late antique date presumed.
See Introduction 2.7.2.
In Greek – ἄρχοντι.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.
See previous note.
For the Bar prefix see Introduction 2.2.1.1.5.
Jewishness indicated by 1. a menorah, see Introduction 6.3.1; and 2. the Hebrew words – שלום שלום שלום (peace, peace, peace), see Introduction 6.2.2.
Found in a Jewish catacomb, see Introduction 6.5.3.

div.note: This is an Idumean theophoric name Kos, see Introduction 1.6.1. The name עבדקוס is recorded for Idumeans, see AOFCI, 84. The name עבדקוסמלך is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 823. The form ‘BDQS is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 400.

עקתא in Aramiac means “anguish, trouble, distress” or “narrow,” see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1109. The form ̓̀Ακετος is recorded on an 8th C CE papyrus, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 15, but the person under this name here is hardly likely to be an Egyptian.

In Aramaic אגם means “leek or leek-like plant” or “a field which requires clearing.” אגמא means “depression, stagnant water, lake,” or אגמא/עגמא means “grief,” see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 12-3. The form ’JM is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 23. The name אגם/אגמה is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 31-2.

This is probably the name איתיבל recorded in Negev, Qedem32, no. 77. The parallel name איתי אל is recorded in Neh 11:7. Also Greek names with the element ̓Αιθ are recorded in WGE, 33-5. It could be a Greek-Semitic combination with Βήλος as a Semitic-theophoric element (Bel, Baal), see Introduction 1.6.1.

In Aramaic אימתא means “fear-inspiring, powerful” or alternatively “timid,”see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 51-2. The form ’YMT is a recorded (female) name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 89. WGE, 35, records the female name Αἰμάθη in Syria.
In Aramaic and in bibical Hebrew אלוף means “chief, prince,”see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 68. The form ’LF is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 69.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
Probably a Cyrenaican (North African name), see LGPN I, 30.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.

̓Αρβιάνης is the name of a Persian king, see Justi, INB, 21. The name חרבו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 481. The form ḤRBN is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 182. The name Arbinnas is documented as Anatolian, see Zgusta, Anatolische Personennamensippen, 72-3.

חרטה in Aramaic means “regret,” see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 501. חרתא in Aramaic means “a free woman,” see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 508. WGE, 123, gives ̓Αρέτας as the name of several Nabatean kings. His name was probably חרתת. The name חרתת is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 494, and the form ḤRTT is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 182.

WGE, 127, records the name ̓Αρίμαντος for a place in Cyrenaica. Yet in this inscription this is clearly a personal name. Indeed in Cyrenaica, names with the prefix ἀριμ are very common (see LGPN I, 58-9), but not elsewhere (see WGE, 127).

WGE, 127, records this name for a Cyrenaican and a Persian, but the former seems to represent the true provenance of the name. Indeed in Cyrenaica, names with the prefix ἀριμ are very common, see LGPN I, 58-9, devoted to names from Cyrenaica, but not elsewhere, see WGE, 127.

The first four letters of this name (ασκλ) are also those of the Greek deity ̓Ασκλαπιός. Names beginning with these letters abound, see WGE, 158-9. Yet obviously this is not such a name. WGE, 157 records ̓Ασκάλων as the name of a town in Palestine (אשקלון). Perhaps the personal name is derived from the name of this town.

In WGE, 156, the name is recorded but this inscription is the only instance cited. It is not mentioned elsewhere. WGE, 157, also mentions the name ̓Ασιδάτης as a Persian name (and see also Justi, INB, 43). The form ’SDT is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 42.

The form ’̣TM is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 54. The name ̓Ατομνεῦς appears on papyri, see Preisigke, Namenbuch, 64; Foraboschi, Namenbuch, 59. The name Atom is recorded as Persian, see Justi, INB, 50.

This is probably a theophoric name with the Canaanite element בעל, see Introduction 1.6.1. The name בעלנתן is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 189. For a First Temple seal see M. Heltzer, in O. W. Muscarella, Ladders to Heaven: Art Treasures from Land of the Bible (Toronto 1981) 291.

I assume this name is a theophoric Canaanite name with the element בעל, see Introduction 1.6.1, but I have found no name associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.

This is probably an Idumean name which includes the elements בר (=son) and קוס (the Idumean god), see introduction 1.6.1. However as such I have not found it recorded for Idumeans. The form BRQS is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 102.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
בטי means “bottom, bathing basin” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 156. The forms BT‘/BTW are recorded names for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 109.
. I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text

In the Bosphoran Kingdom and Thrace names with the prefix Κάρσα are common (see LGPNIV, 187, devoted to names from this region) but not this name. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
This could be an Anatolian name, see Zgusta, Anatolische Personennamensippen, 36.

In LGPNI (devoted to names from Cyrenaica) this is the only instance where this name is recorded. I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text. CJZC, p. 66, interprets this name as deriving from the biblical חולדה (2 Kgs 22:14), but this is unlikely, as the name was never used by Jews, and certainly not for men.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
Greek names with the prefix κοκ and κοκκ abound, see WGE, 686-7, but not this one.
The element Kos refers to an Idumean deity present in many Idumean names, see AOFCI, p. 100. This name is probably קוסעקב, see Introduction 1.6.1, but the name is not recorded elsewhere.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
The form ’̣TT is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 53.
RNGCL, 333, records the Latin cognomen “Flos.” The form FLS is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 470.
This name may derive from the name of the region Galilea in Palestine. The name JLL is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 165.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.

The name יפיע is recorded in the Bible both for the (Canaanite) king of Lachish (Josh 10:3) and for a son of David (2 Sam 5:15). It is, however, not clear that this is the name intended here, see Introduction 6.6.3. The form YF is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 678. WGE, 531, records ̓Ιαφά as the name of the town Jaffa in Palestine. Perhaps this is the origin of this name.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
WGE did not know this name. He records on 568 an uncertain ̓Ιρέσιος and on 569 the common ̓̃Ιρος.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.

This is the only person bearing this name mentioned in LGPNI, 240 (devoted to Cyrenaica). I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.

Idumean names with the prefix ית are recorded, see AOFCI, 99, and this person is Idumean. However, I have found no name which is associated with this form. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.

WGEdid not know this form, but see LGPNI, 240 (devoted to names from this region) records the name for persons in Cyrenaica. It may be a Semitic, probably North African, name. The form ’ṬLMN is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 53.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.

The prefix Μαις is found in several Greek names, see WGE, 841, but not this one. It does not have the usual Greek characteristics, and appears in a list of mostly Semitic names. Thus, I suspect it has a Semitic origin as well, or it is a scribal error, or a wrong reading of the text.
WGE, 850, records Μαλοῦς as the name of a river in Arcadia. In LGPN I, 297, this name is recorded 3 times, all of them from Cyrenaica. It is probably a North African name.
Whatever else this name is, it is probably a theophoric name with the Canaanite (later Hebrew) element – אל, see Introduction 1.6.1.

It is interesting that an Israelite by the name of מוקר is recorded on a 7th C BCE ostracon, see I. Beit-Arieh, “A First Temple Period Census Document,” Palestine Exploration Quarterly 115 (1983) 105. However, I doubt whether this name is in any way influenced by it. I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.

The root נבי/נבא means “burst forth, prophesy” in Hebrew, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 868. נבי is recorded as a name on First Temple Hebrew seals, see CWSSS, nos. 379, 530; for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 580; and in Palmyra, see Stark, PNPI, 98.

WGE, 973, records only this name in this form. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text. However, it has the form of a Bosphoran name because many Bosphoran names begin with the prefix Ναν, see LGPN IV, 245-6, devoted to names from this region.

In WGE, 1016, many names beginning with Νοστ, including Νόστιμος, are recorded. The provenance of this person, however, is Latin. Perhaps the name is derived from the Latin gentilium Nosteius, see RNGCL, 128.
A creative reading of this name may identify something like the theophoric ידידאל, see Introduction 1.6.1, although I have found no such recorded name.
The form ’MZ is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 76.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
On this name as deriving from Pesah see Williams, JSJ 36 (2005) 36.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
פטיר means “pure, plain, clear” or “unleaven bread” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1155. The form FTRM is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 462.
The name פלפס is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 966. Negev interprets it as Philippus, but it may be this one.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
This is obviously a Germanic name, see Tacitus, Annals I, LVII. There he mentions Sigismundus as the son of Segestes, a noble of the Germanic tribe of the Cherusci. He lived in the 1st C CE.
According to LGPN IV, 314, devoted to names from this region, Σόγος and Σόγους are Bosphoran names.
The form SLKT is recorded for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 325.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
I have found no word or name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
זבודא in Aramaic means “gift, outfit”, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 378. The name זבודו is recorded for Nabateans, see Negev, Qedem 32, no. 370.
זהרא means “light … brightness, splendour, moon” in Aramaic, see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 382. The form ZHR is a recorded name for Arabs, see Harding, ICPIANI, 302.

זור in Aramaic means “crown, wreath, capsule,” see Jastrow, DTTBYML, 389. Yet, I have found no name which is associated with this form or root. I assume it must be a scribal error or a wrong reading of the text.
